I think you can move `DoFnInvokers.of(OldDoFn)` to runners-core (obviously in a different class), since no user code should ever submit a `DoFn`. It is just for straggling utility bits in runners.
(after the revert, I mean)
Updated name.
Revert looks good if we can get it green.
Failure in Spark runner does not look related, but also does not look like a flake. Investigating.
R: @lukecwik @kennknowles @tgroh @davorbonaci , or anyone else
LGTM
LGTM. Self-merge as appropriate.

This LGTM now! 👍

I have removed the missing `PAssert` detection stuff, so now we're simply detecting abandoned nodes, be it a `PTransform` or a `PAssert`. If there are dangling nodes of both types than `PAssert` takes precedence and it is the one reported to be abandoned.

In addition, `PipelineAbandonedNodeEnforcement` is now active by default
(`enableAutoRunIfMissing` is `false` by default, as it was prior to the latest change).

Let me know how it looks.

P.S.
I'm really contemplating between `Abandoned` and `Dangling` in all that relates to naming. At the moment it is all `abandoned` but for some reason I feel that `dangling` might be more intuitive for users to understand and relate to. 
Plus, if I were a node I think I would prefer to be `dangling` rather than `abandoned`.

Any thoughts? :)

P.S.^2
I think it's worth mentioning that since now that `TestPipeline` is a `TestRule`, it should be treated somewhat carefully in the presence of other `TestRule`s that alter execution flows by overriding `TestRule#apply()`, e.g. the `ExpectedException` rule which is so commonly used. By carefully, I mean one should consider the order of the `TestRule`s present in a test class. For example (taken from the test suite for `TestPipeline` as a JUnit rule):
```java
@Rule
public RuleChain ruleOrder = RuleChain.outerRule(exception).around(pipeline);
```
It may be hard to determine which combination is the RIGHT one because it depends on the user's expectation of a given test, so this note is here to bring it up as a consideration.

Thanks! I'll merge it shortly.

I took the liberty of moving the methods of `TestPipelineRuleTest` to `TestPipelineTest`, following the same change made to the main class.

This uncovered something I overlooked in review - if there is a method like

```java
@Test public void noop() {}` 
```

it would fail, because the `@Rule TestPipeline` was never run. So you couldn't mix `TestPipeline` tests and other kinds of tests in the same test class. I added a tiny check to be OK if the pipeline is still empty.

If you are interested in following up, we could use a pass through our test suites to convert them to use the `@Rule` form, so they set a good example.

The build is timing out at 100 minutes. In the ~30 seconds I spent looking at the log, the timeout does occur in the Spark integration tests and I don't see anything else obvious. Is it possible there is some retry loop happening?

#1640 should make it easier to quickly estimate issue in cases like this.

Separate from that, I believe we have surefire configured to redirect test method output to a file, but I don't know that the file is archived or accessible, so it might be hard to diagnose until that is changed, too.

@wikier I don't think this PR makes sense as the pluginManagement from the Apache POM already does the gpg sign:

http://repo.maven.apache.org/maven2/org/apache/apache/18/apache-18.pom

```
<!--
 We want to sign the artifact, the POM, and all attached artifacts 
-->
<plugin>
<groupId>org.apache.maven.plugins</groupId>
<artifactId>maven-gpg-plugin</artifactId>
<executions>
<execution>
<id>sign-release-artifacts</id>
<goals>
<goal>sign</goal>
</goals>
</execution>
</executions>
</plugin>
```

I would close this PR (I let a comment in the Jira as well).
